Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. They do not cultivate wholesome roots and dedicate them to supreme, perfect enlightenment only for the sake of one sentient being;

In this way, they do not merely arouse great wisdom and vows in order to purify a single buddha-land, or merely in order to believe in a single buddha, or merely in order to see a single buddha, or merely in order to understand a single dharma, and dedicate them to supreme, perfect enlightenment;

In order to universally purify all buddha-lands, universally believe in all buddhas, universally serve and make offerings to all buddhas, and universally understand all buddha-dharmas, they arouse great vows, cultivate wholesome roots, and dedicate them to supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Buddha's disciple!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, taking the buddhas' dharmas as their objects, give rise to an expansive mind, an irreversible mind, and a mind that is a rare and difficult-to-obtain treasure cultivated over immeasurable eons, equal to all buddhas.

The bodhisattva observes all wholesome roots in this way, with a pure mind of faith, firm great compassion, a profoundly sincere mind, a joyful mind, a pure mind, a supreme mind, a gentle mind, a mind of kindness and compassion, a mind of pity and protection, a mind of benefit, and a mind of peace and happiness. He universally dedicates for the sake of sentient beings, not just with words.
Buddha's disciple!
When the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva dedicates all wholesome roots, he thinks like this:
'With my wholesome roots, I wish that all beings born in all destinies will attain purity;
Their merits will be perfect and complete, indestructible, and inexhaustible;
They will always be respected and their right mindfulness will not be forgotten;
They will attain definitive wisdom and possess immeasurable knowledge;
Their physical, verbal, and mental actions and all merits will be perfectly adorned.'
He also thinks like this:
'By these wholesome roots, may all sentient beings serve and make offerings to all Buddhas without fail;
in the presence of the Buddhas, may their pure faith be indestructible;
may they listen to the true Dharma, cut off all doubts, remember it without forgetting, and practice as taught;
in the presence of the TathÄgatas, may they give rise to a respectful mind, and with pure physical actions, may they abide in immeasurable vast wholesome roots;
may they forever leave poverty behind and be replete with the seven riches;

may they always follow and practice in the presence of the Buddhas, accomplish immeasurable supreme and wonderful wholesome roots, equally awaken and understand, abide in omniscience, and regard sentient beings with unobstructed eyes;
may their bodies be adorned with all the major and minor marks, without any defects;
may their speech be pure and wonderful, their merits be perfect, their faculties be subdued, they accomplish the ten powers, their wholesome mind be replete, and they abide without reliance.
May all sentient beings universally attain the bliss of the Buddhas, attain immeasurable abodes, and abide in the abode of the Buddhas.'
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas see that all sentient beings create evil karma and experience heavy suffering;
Because of these hindrances, they do not see the Buddha, do not hear the Dharma, and do not recognize the Saá¹ƒgha.
They then think like this:
'I should replace all sentient beings in those evil destinies and experience various sufferings on their behalf, enabling them to be liberated.'
When the bodhisattva experiences such bitter suffering, he becomes even more diligent, not abandoning, avoiding, being startled, frightened, retreating, or timid, and has no weariness.
Why is this?
Because he resolutely wishes to bear the burden and enable all sentient beings to attain liberation, just as he has vowed.
At that time, the bodhisattva thinks like this:

'All sentient beings are in places of suffering such as birth, old age, sickness, and death. Following their karma, they transmigrate, have wrong views and lack wisdom, and lose all wholesome dharmas. I should save them and enable them to escape.'

Moreover, sentient beings are entangled in the net of craving, covered by the veil of delusion, attached to various existences, following them without letting go, entering the cage of suffering, performing the actions of Mara, completely exhausting their blessings and wisdom, always harboring doubts, not seeing a place of peace and security, not knowing the path of liberation, revolving in the cycle of birth and death without rest, always sinking in the mire of suffering.

Having seen this, the Bodhisattva gives rise to a mind of great compassion and great benefit, wishing for sentient beings to attain liberation, dedicating all wholesome roots, dedicating with an expansive mind, as practiced by the Bodhisattvas of the three times, as explained in the Mahayana Sutra of Supreme Dedication, vowing for sentient beings to attain purity and ultimately accomplish omniscience.
He further thinks:

'The practice I cultivate is to enable all sentient beings to attain the unsurpassed wisdom king. I do not seek liberation for myself, but only to rescue all sentient beings, enabling them to attain the mind of omniscience and cross the flow of birth and death, liberating them from all suffering.
' He further thought:
'I will universally undergo all sufferings on behalf of all sentient beings, enabling them to escape from the great abyss of immeasurable birth and death and suffering.

I will universally, for all sentient beings, in all worlds and all evil destinies, throughout the future eons, undergo all sufferings, yet always diligently cultivate wholesome roots for the sake of sentient beings.
Why is this?
I would rather alone undergo such sufferings than allow sentient beings to fall into hell.

I will, in those hells, animal realms, and realms of the king of the dead, in those perilous places, take on their suffering and redeem all the sentient beings in the evil paths, enabling them to attain liberation.'
He further thinks like this:
'I vow to protect all sentient beings and never abandon them. What I say is true and without falsehood.
Why is this?

I give rise to the mind of enlightenment in order to save and liberate all sentient beings, not for myself to seek the unsurpassed path, nor to seek the various pleasures of the five desires and the three realms of existence, and therefore cultivate the practices of enlightenment.
Why is this?
The pleasures of the world are all suffering.
The realm of the demons, which foolish people crave and which the Buddhas rebuke, gives rise to all suffering and calamity;
hell, hungry ghosts, animals, and the realm of King Yama, with anger, disputes, and mutual slander.
Such evils are all caused by attachment to the five desires.
Attachment to the five desires keeps one far away from the Buddhas, obstructs rebirth in the heavens, let alone attaining supreme, perfect enlightenment!

The bodhisattva observes in this way that the world experiences immeasurable suffering for the sake of a little bit of the taste of desire, and therefore never seeks unsurpassed enlightenment or cultivates the bodhisattva practices for the sake of the five desires and pleasures;

But only for the sake of bringing peace and happiness to all sentient beings, they give rise to the mind of enlightenment and cultivate and fulfill their great vows, cutting off the nets of suffering for sentient beings and enabling them to attain liberation.
Buddha's disciple!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva further thinks like this:

'I should use the roots of goodness to make such a turning, enabling all sentient beings to attain ultimate happiness, beneficial happiness, unconditioned happiness, tranquil happiness, happiness without reliance, unmoving happiness, immeasurable happiness, happiness that is not abandoned or regressed, happiness that is not extinguished, and the happiness of omniscience.'
He further thinks like this:

'I should be a charioteer for all sentient beings, a general who holds a great torch of wisdom, shows the path of peace and security, enables them to leave behind dangers and difficulties, and with skillful means, I will know the true meaning;
In the ocean of birth and death, they become skillful captains of the ship of omniscience, delivering all beings to the other shore.
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas dedicate their roots of goodness in this way, namely:

'According to their needs, they rescue and protect all beings, enabling them to be born in the ocean of birth and death, to serve and make offerings to all buddhas, to attain unobstructed omniscience, to abandon the mÄras, to stay far away from evil companions, to be close to all bodhisattva good friends, to extinguish all faults and offenses, to accomplish pure karma, and to perfect the bodhisattvas' vast vows and immeasurable roots of goodness.'
Buddha's disciple!
After bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have correctly dedicated their roots of goodness, they think like this:
'It is not because there are many beings in the four continents that many suns appear;
But with just one sun rising, it is able to universally illuminate all beings.
Moreover, all sentient beings do not know day and night by their own light, but travel and observe, engaging in various activities;
all are accomplished by the appearance of the sun, but that sun disc is only one, not two.
' The Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is also like this. When cultivating and accumulating wholesome roots and dedicating them, he thinks like this:
'Those sentient beings cannot save themselves, so how can they save others?
Only I, alone, with no companion, cultivate and accumulate wholesome roots and dedicate them in this way.
Namely:

In order to extensively liberate all sentient beings, to universally illuminate all sentient beings, to guide all sentient beings, to enlighten all sentient beings, to look back on all sentient beings, to embrace all sentient beings, to accomplish all sentient beings, to cause all sentient beings to rejoice, to cause all sentient beings to delight, to cause all sentient beings to end their doubts.
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva should further think like this:
I should be like the sun, universally illuminating everything, not seeking gratitude or reward.
If sentient beings have evil, I can fully tolerate and accept it, and will never abandon my vows because of this;

Not creating dualistic characteristics, not practicing all-inclusive wisdom based on karma, not dedicating all-inclusive wisdom apart from karma, all-inclusive wisdom is not identical to karma, yet all-inclusive wisdom is not attained apart from karma.
Because karma is pure like a shadow or reflection, its retribution is also pure like a shadow or reflection;
Because retribution is as pure as light and shadow, the wisdom of omniscience is also as pure as light and shadow.
Free from the thoughts and discriminations of self and what belongs to self, all agitation, one should understand in this way and skillfully dedicate the roots of goodness.
When the bodhisattva thus makes this dedication, he always delivers sentient beings without rest, not dwelling on the characteristics of dharmas;
although he knows that all dharmas have no karma and no retribution, he is well able to give rise to all karmic retributions without contradiction, and thus skillfully cultivates and dedicates.
When the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva makes this kind of dedication, he is free from all faults and is praised by the buddhas.
Buddha's disciple!
This is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's first dedication, which is to deliver all sentient beings and be free from the characteristics of sentient beings.
